lesson.title: Underground Mysteries
lesson.sentence: You may think that our knowledge of Earth is as solid as the ground beneath our feet. However, although scientists know some important facts about Earth’s crust, many details are a mystery. To solve some of those mysteries, a group of Russian scientists drilled the deepest hole on the planet. Starting in the 1960s, researchers and special drillers began digging and drilling a hole in the northwestern part of Russia, on the Kola Peninsula. Before they were done, the Kola Superdeep Borehole was more than 7.5 miles deep. Researchers unearthed many fascinating facts. Miles below the surface, they found rock that was full of water, like a sponge. Scientists believed that the water had formed from extreme pressure inside the rock. The researchers also found a layer of tiny fossils about four miles down, deeper than anyone expected to "nd fossils. Another surprise was that Earth became much hotter—over 350°F—as drillers dug deeper. Eventually, the drilling area became so hot that the drill bits melted. New holes would close as soon as they were dug. Realizing that better technology was needed, the team stopped drilling in 1994. The deepest hole ever drilled by humans was abandoned, but researchers at new sites continue to investigate the mysteries within Earth’s crust.
